awd_titl_txt: Study of the Solar Dynamics and its Evolution During Cycle 23 Based on an Improved Mode Fitting of a Solar Cycle Worth of Global Oscillation Network Group (GONG) Observations
awd_abstract_narration:
The Principal Investigator's objective is to infer the properties of internal solar rotation and its evolution during Solar Cycle 23, in order to provide key observational constraints on solar dynamo models. He plans to use an improved set of mode frequencies derived from nearly 13 years of Global Oscillation Network Group (GONG) observations. He will fit time series of various durations using a state-of-the-art methodology developed from past spacecraft observations, and then invert the resulting mode sets to obtain improved mode characteristics. 

The PI notes that this effort is timely, since the existing GONG data-fitting methodology was developed nearly 20 years ago and is not optimal. He expects his new fitting technique to be superior and to result in improved mode characteristics for GONG data. The proposer notes that the application of this technique to time series of GONG spherical harmonics coefficients will result in substantially improvements to assessments of solar internal structure, dynamics, and evolution.

This work will increase the scientific return of the NSF-funded GONG project and will help address key scientific questions about solar variability. The PI's derived mode characteristics (frequency, line-width, asymmetry, and so forth) will be made freely available to the research community for additional scientific studies. The new fitting methodology will be provided to GONG project personnel, to allow them to integrate it into their standard data reduction process if deemed appropriate. The results from this effort also will complement existing analyses of older space-based data sets, will provide a unique cross-validation of these independent data sets fitted using the same methodology, and will allow the application of new state-of-the-art analysis techniques to Solar Cycle 24 data to be obtained by new solar instruments recently placed in orbit.

por.por_cntn:
I have reduced all the available GONG data taken since mid-1995 and until
mid-2015, .i.e., 20 years of observations covering all of Cycle 23 (May 1996
to January 2008) and the first half of Cycle 24, including the unsual long
inter-cycle minimun, as solar activity did not resume until early 2010, using
my independent mode fitting procedure.

 I have derived mode characteristics (frequency, line width, asymmetry, and
power) for degrees up to l=200 and for segments of varying lengths, some as
short as 36 days long and some as long as 4,608 days long (12.6 years or a
full solar cycle), using a 36-day, 72-day, 144-day long, etc, progression,
with a 50% overlap when analyzing longer time series.  My fitting methodology
uses not only an optimized spectral estimator (a sine multi-tapered estimator
whose number of tapers is adjusted to match the mode line width), but our best
estimate of the complete leakage matrix.

  The resulting mode characteristics differ from the GONG project values in
different aspects. First, I have fitted time series of varying lengths, using
as baseline the 72-day long time series to match the results from the MDI and
HMI observations. Then I used time series of increasing lengths, 2x, 4x, 8x,
etc... up to 64x 72-day long ones to trade reduced temporal resolution for
increased precision. I eventually also reduced the time series lengths to 36
days to increase the temporal resolution.  Indeed, all things being equal,
statistics tell us that the precision increase by a factor equal to the square
root of the increase in time.  We need this increase in precision to probe
deeper into the Sun, while intuition suggests that changes seated deep into
the Sun ought to occur on a longer time scale.

  An other difference in the properties of the mode characteristics derived by
my methodology is the drastically improved mode attrition.  Some 170,000
individual modes, between degree l=1 and l=200, can be fitted using 72-day
long GONG observations, while the some 17 years of observations have been
divided in 88 epochs, each 72 days long. The methodology used by the GONG
project, using 108-day long time series, staggered every 36 days, produces
sets of mode that change from epoch to epoch with only 10% of modes fitted all
the time - or a very high attrition rate.  By contrast, my methodology
produces nearly the same mode set every time. This becomes important when
trying to detect subtle changes inside the Sun, like changes of the solar
rotation rate. Indeed, we do not measure this rate directly (except at the
surface). We derive it using inversion methods, by the effect the rotation has
on the mode frequencies. Such inversion is conceptually similar to deducing
the 3D shape of an object from looking closely at a large set of its shadow,
each projected along a different direction. If one try to detect a subtle
change of the object's shape over time, but do not have each time the same set
of projections, one can be led to infer the wrong change of shape because a
given set of projections were missing. Having the same mode set (the same set
of projections) every time (or almost) gives us more confidence in the subtle
changes we deduce. Changes with time in the Sun are most likely due to changes
of the solar activity.  This activity is driven by the solar cycle whose
mechanism we have yet to fully understand.
